The key distinction when you're interested in natural systems, engineered systems, the degree to which you can draw inspiration from one and apply it to the other is the extent to which engineered systems tend to.
Exhibit hierarchies.
We like to organize things like this part, whole relationships, strict relationships between levels of description or levels of authority, because they generate well ordered behavior.
And also.
The next thing I know also they give accountability so we know that if this team does better than this team.
You know we can.
We can sort of follow up the chain of command and find out why was it down to the individual team members or the team leader.
Or was it just the boss have a different relationship to this team that team related to this team leader?
You can start to find faults, point the finger apportion blame or.
Whatever the opposite of blame is credit.
In contrast, natural systems don't often exhibit hierarchies, although they are there.
The pecking order of chickens, for example, or the ranking of primates, the Alpha male, and a beta males, but often.
Often the complex systems that we're interested in have more of a many to many relationship.
And yet they still look.
So the reason that we're interested in them is that you still find well ordered behavior in some systems like this, but it's harder to apportion blame for failure.
It's harder to find the aunt that was responsible for the foraging going wrong, or the person in the stock market who precipitated.
You know some terrible crash.

Most most interesting systems are never stable.

Stability and also another way in which stability is interesting.

Some some sense in which the perspectives offered by complexity science change your idea about what it is to intervene in systems.
So I think if you treat systems as simple systems, then there's a sense in which you can control them.
By intervening, you just change, you change the.
The age of consent and that brings about the required or desired change in society.
And by social engineering is just a matter of setting laws, but from a complex systems perspective it's more you get the impression that maybe you're just going to have to continually intervene.
Continually massage a system to keep it doing the things that you're interested in, because it's not just going to passively be pushed around by the interventions that you want to make.

Is strongly.
Of interest to people who are studying complex systems has been called emergence.
It's not unproblematic.

So key a key observation for complex systems, systems that appear disordered at a low level so ants the people in crowds people in economies may nevertheless exhibit ordered behavior at a higher level.
OK, so this is the kind of I guess one of the central insights and the central attractions of the complex systems perspective, and here.

Is Jupiter's red spot.

There, all influx across Jupiter surface.

That's arising out of the.

It's as though an invisible hand pushes the market as a whole to be to exhibit this ordered behavior of equilibrating to.

Fashion cycles.
There's a whole class of these sorts of behavior where people.
Invoke something called downward causation.
So there's a notion that in some systems, the global level behavior that emerges from the low level entities can feedback directly onto the low level entities.
If those entities are special.
If their special in the sense that they can detect these, they can sort of directly detect the global level phenomenon.

It looks like.
The entities that make up your system have to kind of be people because it's difficult to imagine.

It's difficult to talk about downward causation because it invokes processes that take place across levels of description, which is typically not admitted within physical physicalist descriptions of systems.
But we'll come back to that when we talk about emergence more.

Things that taste like this nice to eat, then they change their behavior patterns or when they learn that things that taste like this make them sick, then they change their behavior patterns.

Imitation is a special kind of learning, so maybe people on the Stock Exchange always looking over their shoulder trying to see what the other guy is doing, changing their behavior in response to whether they see another person succeeding at what they're doing or not.
So that can lead to the system as a whole, adapting very rapidly in response to changes in the environment.

Any kind of competition where their scarce resource is so pop bands compete for an audience and you see the nature of what it is to be a pop band, changing gradually as the nature of the audience changes the environment that they're adapting to.
So you know, boy bands.

I've changed over the years in response to the changing sophistications of the tastes of young girls, but the changing tastes of young girls that have also been influenced by what pop bands have been available.
So here you've got coadaptation.

The key distinction when you're interested in natural systems, engineered systems, the degree to which you can draw inspiration from one and apply it to the other is the extent to which engineered systems tend to.
Exhibit hierarchies.
We like to organize things like this part, whole relationships, strict relationships between levels of description or levels of authority, because they generate well ordered behavior.
And also.
The next thing I know also they give accountability so we know that if this team does better than this team.
You know we can.
We can sort of follow up the chain of command and find out why was it down to the individual team members or the team leader.
Or was it just the boss have a different relationship to this team that team related to this team leader?
You can start to find faults, point the finger apportion blame or.
Whatever the opposite of blame is credit.
In contrast, natural systems don't often exhibit hierarchies, although they are there.
The pecking order of chickens, for example, or the ranking of primates, the Alpha male, and a beta males, but often.
Often the complex systems that we're interested in have more of a many to many relationship.
And yet they still look.
So the reason that we're interested in them is that you still find well ordered behavior in some systems like this, but it's harder to apportion blame for failure.
It's harder to find the aunt that was responsible for the foraging going wrong, or the person in the stock market who precipitated.
You know some terrible crash.
